image.altText: A map of Australia with multiple curving orange lines crossing it in different directions.

image.altText: A man and a woman hug, and laugh

image.altText: Michael Parkinson

image.altText: A male politican in a blue suit and white tie, speaking at a lecturn in front of a sign that reads 'working for Australia'

items.synopsis: Labor is less than halfway into its first term, but Anthony Albanese knows if he leads a short-term government, what it achieves can be quickly negated. His message to delegates at the national conference is "be patient", writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Anthony Albanese had one clear message for delegates at Labor's national conference

image.altText: Several boats are moored at a marina, with palm trees in the background and a shed on the shore

items.synopsis: When two boats set off towards an Indonesian island for a birthday surfing trip, none of those on board could have predicted the next few days. Here's how the survivors managed more than 36 hours at sea.

title.children: How dangerous weather turned a fun surfing trip into a nightmare 36 hours lost at sea

image.altText: Sun setting through a line of transmission towers

items.synopsis: Across Australia, governments have set ambitious goals for turning their power systems green. But a decision to keep a coal plant running longer suggests the rhetoric is not matched by the reality.

title.children: 'Reality catching up with rhetoric' as coal-fired closure delayed

image.altText: The logo of SA Police on the glass window of a police station.

items.synopsis: A 26-year-old man, the fifth person to be arrested and charged over the alleged rape of a woman in June, will face court in Adelaide, after being extradited on Thursday.

title.children: Fifth man charged over alleged rape in Adelaide's west extradited from Victoria

image.altText: A man wearing a vest that says vision impaired, in the snow with skis

items.synopsis: With a guide following him calling out the turns, Pete Ellson hurtles down the slopes at Falls Creek watched on by everyone on the mountain.

title.children: 'Awe-inspiring' blind 76yo skier takes to the slopes

image.altText: a man wearing a suit and tie talking at a reporter on a bright sunny street

items.synopsis: Standing outside Sydney’s Downing Centre courthouse on Thursday, a survivor of child sexual abuse reflected on the pain he has felt for 45 years.

title.children: Hillsong founder Brian Houston was found not guilty — but one man has been left with a 'life sentence'

image.altText: Close up of Britney Spears in a dress and necklace standing next to Sam Asghari in a suit and tie. Other people walk behind them

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Britney Spears's husband Sam Asghari files for divorce. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By North America correspondent Barbara Miller Authorities in the US state of Georgia are investigating online threats against the jurors who voted this week to indict Donald Trump and 18 others over an alleged conspiracy to overturn the 2020 presidential election results. Unlike in federal and many other state cases, the names of those jurors are listed in the indictment, which has reportedly led to doxing. In a statement, the Fulton County Sheriff’s office says it "is aware that personal information of members of the Fulton County Grand Jury is being shared on various platforms". The Sheriff’s office says the matter is being taken "very seriously" and it’s working to track down the origins of the threats. Some online posts reportedly suggested jurors were harassed, but it’s not clear whether that has actually happened. It all adds to the tension around Fulton County, Atlanta, where Trump and his co-defendants have been given until the end of next week to appear at the Rice Street jail to be booked in the case, which is expected to involve the former president having his mugshot taken.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Threats have reportedly been made against jurors who voted to indict Donald Trump in Georgia

children.content: By North America correspondent Barbara Miller

Authorities in the US state of Georgia are investigating online threats against the jurors who voted this week to indict Donald Trump and 18 others over an alleged conspiracy to overturn the 2020 presidential election results.
Unlike in federal and many other state cases,
the names of those jurors are listed in the indictment, which has reportedly led to doxing.

props.alt: A group of police and security personel standing outside of a courthouse

children.content: (AP: Ben Gray)
In a statement, the Fulton County Sheriff’s office says it "is aware that personal information of members of the Fulton County Grand Jury is being shared on various platforms".
The Sheriff’s office says the matter is being taken "very seriously" and it’s working to track down the origins of the threats.
Some online posts reportedly suggested jurors were harassed, but it’s not clear whether that has actually happened.

It all adds to the tension around Fulton County, Atlanta, where Trump and his co-defendants have been given until the end of next week to appear at the Rice Street jail to be booked in the case, which is expected to involve the former president having his mugshot taken.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Football Australia is hoping the excitement behind the Matildas at the Women's World Cup will put Australia in a strong position to host other upcoming major football events. AAP reports Football Australia is set to challenge Saudi Arabia for hosting rights to the 2026 Women's Asian Cup. The organisation has also been ambitious in its desire to bid for hosting rights to the men's World Cup in 2034 and the revamped Club World Cup in 2029. But the Women's Asian Cup in 2026 looms as a much more attainable proposition. Football Australia CEO James Johnson tells AAP: "(A successful bid) would extend this window for a major growth in the Australian game which is really being turbocharged by the women's game. "There's a lot of logic for that bid, it's calculated because women's football is growing rapidly around the world and in particular in Australia. "We've seen the success of the Matildas at this World Cup and we know when we hosted the Asian Cup in 2015 that was a big success. "We're taking it seriously and we're working with state and federal governments to make sure we have the right backing to get that over the line."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: As the Matildas prepare for Sweden, Football Australia prepares to bid for more local events

props.alt: Sam Kerr smiles and gives a thumbs up while walking into the changerooms at a football stadium. Fans in the stands behind clapping

children.content: (Getty Images: FIFA/Maddie Meyer)
Football Australia is hoping the excitement behind the Matildas at the Women's World Cup will put Australia in a strong position to host other upcoming major football events.
AAP reports Football Australia is set to challenge Saudi Arabia for hosting rights to the 2026 Women's Asian Cup.
The organisation has also been ambitious in its desire to bid for hosting rights to the men's World Cup in 2034 and the revamped Club World Cup in 2029.
But the Women's Asian Cup in 2026 looms as a much more attainable proposition.
Football Australia CEO James Johnson tells AAP:
"(A successful bid) would extend this window for a major growth in the Australian game which is really being turbocharged by the women's game.
"There's a lot of logic for that bid, it's calculated because women's football is growing rapidly around the world and in particular in Australia.
"We've seen the success of the Matildas at this World Cup and we know when we hosted the Asian Cup in 2015 that was a big success.
"We're taking it seriously and we're working with state and federal governments to make sure we have the right backing to get that over the line."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Canadian woman has been sentenced to nearly 22 years in jail in the US for sending letters containing the potentially deadly poison ricin to Donald Trump when he was US president. Pascale Ferrier, 56, agreed to the sentence in January after pleading guilty to biological weapons charges. The deadly letter for Trump was intercepted in September 2020, before it could reach the White House. Ferrier also admitted to sending similarly tainted letters to eight Texas law enforcement officials.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woman sentenced to almost 22 years in jail for sending poison to Donald Trump

props.alt: Donald Trump in a suit and tie standing in front of a microphone

children.content: (AP: Butch Dill)
A Canadian woman has been sentenced to nearly 22 years in jail in the US for sending letters containing the potentially deadly poison ricin to Donald Trump when he was US president.
Pascale Ferrier, 56, agreed to the sentence in January after pleading guilty to biological weapons charges.
The deadly letter for Trump was intercepted in September 2020, before it could reach the White House.
Ferrier also admitted to sending similarly tainted letters to eight Texas law enforcement officials.

image.altText: A grinning man smiles as he looks down at his smiling bride, with her white veil pulled back over her head.

items.synopsis: China's infamous censors are methodical about keeping the country's closed internet free from information that the ruling Communist Party does not want its citizens seeing, but a new report from Human Rights Watch finds racist content on the Chinese internet targeting black people has become common.

title.children: China is big on internet censorship unless it's racist content, Human Rights Watch says

image.altText: Small shrubs planted in red dirt.

image.altText: A submarine is seen on the surface of the water in front of mountains and clear skies.

image.altText: A younger and older portrait of a man.

title.children: Our Vietnam War was more than the hundreds killed — the aftermath was confronting for the 60,000 who served

image.altText: An overview of some vegetables including cherry tomatoes, button mushrooms, green  beans and yellow capsicum

image.altText: A man wearing a navy blue shirt with Australian Aid on it checks pallets of boxes.

title.children: Australia is spending $4.77 billion on foreign aid this year, but is it enough?

image.altText: A smiling young boy with fair hair sits among giant plastic blocks of chocolate.

items.synopsis: Nicholas Henry died in 2021 after he was bashed and stabbed eight times in Morwell, Victoria. Three of those involved have been sentenced in the Supreme Court, but Mr Henry's sister says it "doesn't feel like justice".

title.children: 'How can this be real?' Sister in disbelief that killers who 'hunted down' defenceless brother could be free in three years

image.altText: Sir Michael Parkinson smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: A statement from Parkinson's family said the veteran broadcaster died after a brief illness.

image.altText: A young Indigenous woman smiling out the front of a home

items.synopsis: Indigenous mother-of-four Charlotte Dodds was working as a disability support worker when she started to feel unwell. At age 30, she didn't recognise the stroke symptoms.

image.altText: Female in yellow soccer jersey standing next to the goalposts.

items.synopsis: Sarah Langman is a goalkeeper for the Central Coast Mariners and has been playing for the A-League for nine seasons. But the disparity in pay and the part-time nature of the women's league in Australia means she can't focus on football full time.

image.altText: A hazy red sky over federation square full of people

items.synopsis: Melbourne's Federation Square has been axed as a live site for the remainder of the Women's World Cup due to dozens of flares being let off within the capacity crowd there during Wednesday night's semifinal.

image.altText: A woman in a dark beanie and hoodie in a park

items.synopsis: Stronger police powers aimed at reducing anti-social behaviour in Adelaide's CBD will "put fear" into First Nations Australians gathering in the city, a Kaurna elder says. But police say the laws are "being applied equally".

image.altText: Maatsuyker island lighthouse, Tasmania

items.synopsis: If you've ever been for a dip in the ocean, you know the warmth of the water can vary wildly. On a grand scale, sea surface temperatures also play a significant role in the weather around you, writes the Bureau of Meteorology's Matthew Thomas.

title.children: Above and below the sea, how do ocean temperatures influence Tasmania's weather?

image.altText: A young man stands with an older woman in front of microphones.

items.synopsis: Billionaire miner Gina Rinehart threatened her son John Hancock when he tried to find out about what had happened to his inheritance, the WA Supreme Court is told, at a time when he was so hard up for cash he couldn't even afford new brake pads for his car.

image.altText: Owen Farrell stands with his hands on his hips

title.children: England's skipper should have been banned for six weeks, but World Rugby 'critically undermined' its own guidelines

image.altText: Sam Williamson bursts out of the water wearing an Australian gold swimming cap

image.altText: Rachel Zegler stands and smiles at a press event.

items.synopsis: Resurfaced comments made by actress Rachel Zegler about her upcoming live-action remake of Disney's Snow White spark outrage online.

title.children: 'The original came out in 1937, and evidently so': Actress Rachel Zegler's Snow White interview goes viral

image.altText: A crocodile sits on a sandy bank while a man fishes nearby

items.synopsis: A viral online video showing a man fishing near a large croc has left authorities dismayed and locals concerned for the future of the well-known reptile.

title.children: Authorities warn against 'life-threatening risks' after man filmed fishing metres from saltwater crocodile
